plants.name: Rosa spp.
plants.description: Roses are widely cultivated flowering shrubs known for their large, fragrant blooms and thorny stems. They bloom prolifically in late spring through summer in temperate zones.
plants.location: Northern Hemisphere temperate gardens, including North America, Europe, and parts of Asia
plants.funFact: Roses have been cultivated for over 5,000 years and are symbols of love and beauty in many cultures.

plants.name: Lupinus polyphyllus
plants.description: Bigleaf lupines produce tall spikes covered in dense clusters of pea-like flowers. They are commonly found in wild meadows and garden settings, attracting pollinators.
plants.bloomingSeason: Late spring to mid-summer (May to July)
plants.location: Western North America, especially in the Pacific Northwest
plants.funFact: Lupines enrich the soil by fixing nitrogen via bacteria in their root nodules, improving soil fertility.

plants.name: Banksia integrifolia
plants.description: Coast Banksia is a coastal Australian tree that produces cylindrical flower spikes composed of many tiny flowers, blooming profusely during early winter into late spring and sometimes into early summer.
plants.funFact: Banksias are important for native wildlife as their flowers provide nectar for birds and insects.

plants.name: Nymphaea odorata
plants.description: This aquatic plant features large, fragrant white flowers that float on the surface of ponds and lakes, blooming in warm months.
plants.location: Freshwater bodies across much of North America
plants.funFact: Water lilies have stomata only on the upper surface of their leaves to facilitate gas exchange while floating.
